text: My view, could be wrong, is unfashionable - she'll refuse to go anywhere until Brexit happens. We'll see v soon.
author: iainmartin1

text: And yes, ERG could bring down the govt mid-Brexit. What could possibly go wrong?
author: iainmartin1

text: Didn't say I was advocating it! Was reporting what I understand of the plan. There are some, er, flaws in it!
author: iainmartin1

text: Yep
author: iainmartin1

text: We must move in different circles! Lidington as a potential compromise option has been floated by loads of Tories (privately) for ages. First time I heard it was Sept 2017 standing with several MPs at  @GeorgeFreemanMP @BigTentIdeas
author: iainmartin1

text: No-one is certain of anything!
author: iainmartin1

text: Plan as I understand it seems to be that May stands down as PM, then suggests Queen sends for Lidders. She STAYS as Tory leader (mainly to annoy Steve Baker) for ten weeks or so (can't be challenged) to facilitate Brexit compromise. Then leadership election. Lidington 3 month PM
author: iainmartin1

text: Yes, that's the theory. Presumably the ERG would then collapse the govt. Which is a, er, small flaw in the plan.
author: iainmartin1

text: No, she would stay as Tory leader for 10 weeks or so. She'd recommend the Queen sending for DL and step down as PM. That's the theory.
author: iainmartin1

text: Has been rumoured as an option for about a year?
author: iainmartin1

text: I didn't say it was. The march was impressive. I said the clips of the politicians on the 10 looked rubbish.
author: iainmartin1

text: In the short clip there was booing.
author: iainmartin1

text: David Lidington is secretly in the ERG?! This will blow the lid right off the story...
author: iainmartin1

text: Neither was on the 10 - the way most people will, if they see it at all,  see it. It looked dire.
author: iainmartin1

text: Looked shouty and ill-judged.
author: iainmartin1

text: Terrific bloke, very nice, v bright,  grows his own strawberries *one of these facts needs checking.
author: iainmartin1

text: Hundreds of thousands marched, impressive and quite a spectacle. But the clips on the 10 of the rally looked terrible. Sturgeon shouting. Tom Watson being booed. People's Vote will surely be unhappy with how rubbish the politicians looked.
author: iainmartin1

text: Reminder: are 314 Tory MPs. The ERG (which is divided) has perhaps 50 votes (some more MPs are semi-attached to the ERG). Whatever. The ERG does not have anything like a majority and cannot control a Tory leadership race. Goodness, many of the 314 will be out to do in the ERG
author: iainmartin1

text: Perhaps Mrs May will suddenly surrender and step aside, but for all the excitement (and Cabinet carnage) walking away from her post is surely completely at odds with everything we know about May's approach and instincts.
author: iainmartin1

text: So what? Different set of editors in the free press made a different set of judgements. Don't see what it has to do with you, unless you're a Telegraph reader? Suspect you're not.
author: iainmartin1

text: Surely the Belgian intelligence service wasn't so poorly informed as to believe that? What were you thinking at HQ?
author: iainmartin1

text: I don't think they are or will ignore it. The question was whether they're obliged (knowing their own audience in a free country) to put it on their home page. They are not obliged to, no.
author: iainmartin1

text: V funny!
author: iainmartin1

text: Marches, generally, are not news. They are attended by obsessives. This is clearly news because of scale and context. Telegraph (haven't worked for them for years) are not obliged to make their presentational and news judgements according to your pro-EU tastes.
author: iainmartin1

text: Sure they will cover it extensively. Why must it be on the home page?  They're not obliged to do what you want or position it according to your tastes.
author: iainmartin1

text: Didn't say they had. They feel strongly. So do lots of us who belive a promise made to implement the result should be kept.
author: iainmartin1

text: Vote Leave isn't in power? A Remainer became PM. But you accept I hope the basic point that results should - as promised by the state in its 9m quid leaflet drop - be implemented?
author: iainmartin1

text: So what? Telegraph readers won't be very interested in it. Not compulsory to be interested in it.
author: iainmartin1

text: But there was no mention by Remain of this confirmation vote when people voted. You've introduced the concept only after having lost.
author: iainmartin1

text: Love that the countryside alliance march is the one where estimate not inflated and then endorsed by the police.
author: iainmartin1

text: All three of them were there?
author: iainmartin1

text: Small and medium sized marches are common on all manner of worthy and unworthy causes. Progressives, liberals and the left march. Conservatives, generally, don't.
author: iainmartin1

text: Hence the use of the word generally. The primrose league was massive. In the 1890s. Countryside alliance exceptional, and representing a wide spread of non-urban interests, because smug liberal twits had declared war on them.
author: iainmartin1

text: Indeed. There is no govt. And she can't be removed. I'm seeing cabinet ministers cited (wrongly, I think, but who knows) supposedly joining calls for her to go who are really propping her up to get to no deal.
author: iainmartin1

text: Spot on. Can't stand marches or mobs - conservatives generally don't march, too embarrassing and tend to be busy.
author: iainmartin1

text: Richmond very quiet. Was lovely!
author: iainmartin1

text: Why?
author: iainmartin1

text: Calm down Patrick.
author: iainmartin1

text: We succeeded. Osborne is hilarious. Botched austerity, police cuts, garden bridge funding scandal, FTPA, rough-sleeping, HS2, help to buy farce.
author: iainmartin1

text: No it won't.
author: iainmartin1

text: Anything could happen, but as the cabinet squabbles and parliament faffs I suspect May is going nowhere - the supergluing herself to the desk in Number 10 approach.
author: iainmartin1

text: Thank you for the alert, muting you now.
author: iainmartin1

text: Nice person. So liberal.
author: iainmartin1

text: Sure, it's a mess. One of the compensations though is how much Brexit annoys you.
author: iainmartin1

text: Tee hee. Is there a march on?
author: iainmartin1

text: Thanks Martin
author: iainmartin1

text: I know you struggle with seeing things from the perspective of others, but keep trying! And have a nice weekend!
author: iainmartin1

text: it's meant to indicate an upgrade, but generally now is a tired, futile PR device aimed at encouraging people to look again at something they missed the first time round.
author: iainmartin1

text: Wanting a historical legacy explains May being resigned to no deal. (My latest newsletter for Reaction subscribers)
author: iainmartin1

text: but the backstop points (clearly, without doubt) to what Labour says it wants, a customs union and close alignment with the single market. And it pleases the Irish govt, something which has traditionally been Labour policy.
author: iainmartin1

text: This is v good by @PCollinsTimes - Labour (which on the whole doesn't disagree with the terms of the WA) should vote for May's deal. So should the SNP, but won't because Ian "buttons up waistcoat, we are in a crisis" Blackford is playing a Nat game.
author: iainmartin1

text: That's most of the New Club!
author: iainmartin1

text: I was broadly sceptical - country being run from bar of the Corinthia hotel by Chiefs of Staff - but briefly thought when she called the election I had underestimated her. And then... the campaign, and everything since.
author: iainmartin1

text: I will very happily run and promote a piece by you Nick laying it out - on Reaction  @reactionlife . Have read all the various iterations and keen to understand what the plan is now.
author: iainmartin1

text: Nope.
author: iainmartin1

text: Yep, Labour should vote for the deal.
author: iainmartin1

text: Thanks. I think a legitimate compromise proposal (see @GeorgeTrefgarne and @george_yarrow) has been made excessively complicated by MPs.
author: iainmartin1

text: Other than writing about it (my job) endlessly, not much.
author: iainmartin1

text: Ah, the classic Boles outreach!
author: iainmartin1

text: Crucial point. Commons votes for Boles "plan". Number 10 and cabinet say: "This is a joke, it's not a plan, you've just voted for Nick Boles's website."
author: iainmartin1

text: Translation = he and the ridiculous ideas in his book got taken apart.
author: iainmartin1

text: Unfortunately, the Boles plan is the runner. It is over-complicated and botched.
author: iainmartin1

text: It's a website with some aspirations on it. It's a joke. Now about to get a lot scrutiny, I suspect. Wait until you get to the we will then negotiate a derogation from EFTA to allow us to be in a CU bit.
author: iainmartin1

text: Indeed. Boles plan (over-complicated, scope for more infighting) passes. Then what? She'll say - rightly - this is a joke plan that is basically just a website with some aspirations on it about the non-legally binding PD. And then she will refuse to leave Number 10.
author: iainmartin1

text: May is resigned to no deal if her deal falls. First, the country is about to be treated to the interesting spectacle of Letwin trying to get the badly botched and over-complicated @NickBoles plan through, with lots of scope for more fighting.
author: iainmartin1

text: Nietzsche was right: some people are wired to be more spontaneous than others
author: iainmartin1

text: read the piece
author: iainmartin1

text: agree - Labour have rarely been pressed on this.
author: iainmartin1

text: Hello. Honestly, had to review the book. Is not v good.
author: iainmartin1

text: Is it? He got taken apart and his book is dire.
author: iainmartin1

text: Her aides 2016 knew, so take some of the blame. Basically it was an accident. She looked like the only grown up left. People thought, wrongly, she was an enigma. Behind the mask was a great political intelligence. There wasn't.
author: iainmartin1

text: The utlra-remainers? Yes, it is sad to see. #BDS seems to have no cure.
author: iainmartin1

text: That's convinced me! Are you that ex hipster Standard columnist?
author: iainmartin1

text: That's a bit thick? Obviously we don't. But we do hold cards. Being the major security and intelligence power in Europe and having NATO role are obviously a thing. Only an EU fanatic would deny that.
author: iainmartin1

text: Sure, but you would accept that Theresa May, the person in charge when it was triggered, was nothing to do with vote leave? She voted remain.
author: iainmartin1

text: Not glorying in it. Just v keen to leave. We'll need deals, sure. As will they - particularly on security. Oh, and defence.
author: iainmartin1

text: Knife crime wars - the global roots of a national tragedy. (Brilliant long read by Alastair Benn on the true national crisis.)
author: iainmartin1

text: Is extraordinary this assumption. Clever EU. Genius deal. Unless the deal falls. In which case they have been too clever by half and ballsed it up.
author: iainmartin1

text: So no deal it is then.
author: iainmartin1

text: Starting to think you actually work for the titans in the Belgian intelligence agency.
author: iainmartin1

text: Sure - they are a major bloc. And should be a bit friendlier to one of their main export markets and the leading security and intelligence power and their partner in Europe.
author: iainmartin1

text: That's nice.
author: iainmartin1

text: The second largest defence power in NATO, and the leading security and intel power? Very good.
author: iainmartin1

text: You think, in NATO? And on security and intel?
author: iainmartin1

text: Google the story of letting a burglar in for a pee.
author: iainmartin1

text: Oh dear, you've swallowed the EU line.
author: iainmartin1

text: Good for May, for once.
author: iainmartin1

text: Oliver Letwin - Letwin! - and Jeremy Corbyn are going to sort it out, apparently! What could possibly go wrong?
author: iainmartin1

text: Why is the Prime Minister of Luxembourg wearing a Sound of Music jacket? #EuropeanCouncil
author: iainmartin1

text: Watching the EU tonight never loved Brexit more! Honestly, what an appalling bunch.
author: iainmartin1

text: Anyone finding the whole EU27 grilling UK PM then deciding fate of Britain behind closed doors thing making you feel really no dealy?
author: iainmartin1

text: But you're on the side of the EU so would say that?
author: iainmartin1

text: Eh? At least spell my name correctly if you are going to tweet at me like a muppet.
author: iainmartin1

text: The Dutch PM was noticeably less cocky today when talking Brexit. Has there been some kind of election in the Netherlands?...
author: iainmartin1

text: Sure - UK a mess, but EU heading for offering last minute 2 year delay with conditions that reinforce May's determination not to ask for one. EU has from its perspective played a blinder, if the deal passes. If it doesn't pass, EU hasn't played a blinder, it has ballsed it up
author: iainmartin1

text: they removed them, just before he arrived. They're like that, on the cheese and biscuits circuit.
author: iainmartin1

text: very good piece, thanks.
author: iainmartin1

text: He'd look a bit stupid resigning now. Like resigning a commission when the shelling starts.
author: iainmartin1

text: Sorry, cannot respond to FBPE people. Very strict rules on this. Sorry!
author: iainmartin1

text: There is a workable majority in the Commons for passing the WA and then adding in your customs union and membership of the single market? And you'll secure a derogation from EFTA on not taking part in their free trade arrangements? Next week?
author: iainmartin1

text: it's an idea as old as, er, television.
author: iainmartin1

text: Indeed.
author: iainmartin1

text: I question that reference to GFA which had sweet FA to do with the EU. UK govt has not handled it well, no. But the whole thing should have been split into three complementary agreements. Basic withdrawal, future relationship and Irish border (hived off by London and Dublin.)
author: iainmartin1

text: Indeed - the EU's mistake. Embedding the outline future relationship in the WA via the backstop. Too clever by half from Brussels.
author: iainmartin1

text: Indeed. I wouldn't blame him
author: iainmartin1

text: She's increasingly resigned to no deal and two thirds of the cabinet agrees. The Commons could do... what? Might demand she revokes. Parliament cannot be the executive. It has to change the executive.
author: iainmartin1

text: It is a long and tedious story.
author: iainmartin1

text: Despite what he might be starting to believe, Letwin does not have special constitutional status. Even a short extension comes with strict demands, it seems. Long one needs to be asked for by a govt and a PM. EU could try direct negotiation with the Commons. Can't see how.
author: iainmartin1

text: Ryan, I was writing for 18 months that she had to go. We needed a functioning PM in charge. Now some of the people involved who assured me she had it all covered are furious with her. We are where we are. I'll accept no deal and make the best of it, many people won't.
author: iainmartin1

text: they need to start taking it seriously! Danger now is that even if 50 Labour MPs switch it won't be enough. The no dealers in the ERG think it's Christmas.
author: iainmartin1

text: which she won't as PM ask for, she said yesterday. And she won't resign either. So...
author: iainmartin1

text: Thanks Alan, much appreciated - yes Labour could have pivoted to the deal demanding a concession or two and it would all be done. I suspect parliament will demand she asks for a long extension. She won't. And then the final 72 hours will be quite something.
author: iainmartin1

text: dunno - politics gets v weird in a crisis. Did in 2008. Some voters will rise to it. Others will be furious. Others confused and depressed. Depends on handling and blame game, and speed of recovery.
author: iainmartin1

text: it is all about the gram, apparently.
author: iainmartin1

text: They propped her up. And she hasn't prepared properly for no deal. This is on them as well as the EU.
author: iainmartin1

text: nope - no deal will be a mess because the govt has not prepared for it properly. It will be interesting to see which political parties survive. For the economy it's survivable, of course. And many of us will be robust in refusing to beg the EU. But the ERG have ballsed it up.
author: iainmartin1

text: Thanks Zoe
author: iainmartin1

text: $900 per month. Claims 7% acceptance rate. Massive global crash coming.
author: iainmartin1

text: This is spot on, I think. From what I hear May is increasingly resigned to accepting no deal. She'll refuse to ask for a long extension. Parliament cannot agree or work out what to do about it. Cabinet won't remove her. Tory MPs can't. Brexit... in eight days.
author: iainmartin1

text: He won't go either. Peter is right. Smash ahead.
author: iainmartin1

text: It is bizarre. Really very strange to watch.
author: iainmartin1

text: We've all seen assorted PMs make mistakes under pressure. It is a tough job and easy to snipe. Still, have never before seen a PM's "address to the nation" backfire in parliament and beyond quite as badly as the May address did last night. It was an epic error.
author: iainmartin1

text: Sorry.
author: iainmartin1

text: Do you have anything on dysfunctional France?
author: iainmartin1

author: iainmartin1

text: Yes, but not that much. A PM wanting to hold an early election to seek a mandate will always get it. Because the opposition will always say yes. See 2017 early election.
author: iainmartin1

text: Wrong. She is in a leave area, wants leave to happen. The Tories have mishandled their outreach. Idiocy. On Tuesday they helped Corbyn remove @IanAustinMP from select committee. He has voted for the deal. He's pro-Brexit. An anti-Corbyn patriot, and the Tories aided Corbyn.

text: Yep, a great man.
author: iainmartin1

author: iainmartin1

text: yes good point. I was objecting more to her core misunderstanding and assumption that it is there to do what she suggests because she suggests it, invoking the national interest (bogus term). It isn't obliged at all. It can do what it chooses.
author: iainmartin1

text: FTPA? It's a complication, although not insurmountable as demonstrated in 2017.
author: iainmartin1

text: yep, which is where parliament is making its own parallel misunderstanding. If it doesn't want that it has get something else in place or change the executive. No sign it can do either, even now.
author: iainmartin1

text: Parliament is not obliged to do what a PM wants. When a Prime Minister cannot get a Parliament to do what they suggest they can resign or try for a new Parliament via an election. That's the system.

text: Bercow blows up Brexit and points way to long delay or revoking Article 50. (My latest for Reaction @Reactionlife) https://reaction.life/bercow-blows-brexit-points-way-long-delay-revoking-article-50/ …
author: iainmartin1

text: It is quite shameless. Incredible. Burbles on endlessly about everyone else's failings (fine, up to a point, that's hackery). But not a moment of reflection or public admission that he had a lot of power, for seven years, and made some quite serious mistakes.
author: iainmartin1

text: The Church of England makes a vital contribution to national life. (Interesting, upbeat, optimistic by Justin Welby writing for Reaction @reactionlife) https://reaction.life/church-england-makes-vital-contribution-national-life/ …
author: iainmartin1

text: Last done in 1948 under Attlee? I think.
author: iainmartin1

text: Bercow clears the way for long delay or revoking Article 50. Contains multiple insults about the ERG's strategy. My latest newsletter for Reaction subscribers out shortly. Can sign up here: https://reaction.life/become-supporting-member/ …
author: iainmartin1

text: Have read your considered view. I respectfully disagree and think it would be catastrophic for our democracy and society, but add the various factions up and anti-no deal majority is large. If comes down to revoke or no deal, my best guess is that revoke wins.
author: iainmartin1

text: House hates no deal. Imagine it - in a week's time the place will be sitting round the clock and half of them will be wired to the moon. They'll vote to revoke and ram a bill through if it comes to it. Unless a long-ish vague extension agreed with the EU.
author: iainmartin1

text: I agree, I think they're stuffed.
author: iainmartin1

text: no sign enough MPs are up for that, would mean attempting something complex and hard to understand at speed and it's been so mangled by Boles. Revoke has the votes if it's that or no deal.
author: iainmartin1

text: Hardly a complex bill, if an Act is required. There are the numbers for it - during a short extension. Goodness half the ERG wants it revoked. Bulk of Labour, SNP, Liberals.
author: iainmartin1

text: What if it doesn't? Honestly, I'm a Brexiteer and I'm sick of Brexiteers  making dark or overoptimistic predictions that come to nothing.
author: iainmartin1

text: ERG die hards celebrating that no deal is back on the table don't seem to have worked out that if it comes to it there are probably the votes in the chamber to revoke in an emergency and Bercow will facilitate it.
author: iainmartin1

text: They didn't make a 6 did they?
author: iainmartin1

text: At least we'll be spared Meaningul Vote 5, which was shaping up to be less believable than Police Academy 5
author: iainmartin1

text: By putting no deal back on the table?
author: iainmartin1

text: Character limit, but yes that was on his watch.
author: iainmartin1

text: What a brass neck this bloke has, as the consequences of his failings in office mount up. Failure to plan for losing referendum, policing cutbacks, housing market, and the small matter of the garden bridge funding scandal.
author: iainmartin1

text: This is the Commons equivalent of a drum solo, going on way too long now.
author: iainmartin1

text: Perhaps you weren't here for the 18 months from election 2017 until leadership challenge - during which the ERG propped up May. Some of us said and wrote she needed to go, but were told smugly by ERG that she should stay.
author: iainmartin1

text: Indeed. Have never heard it suggested at any point that he would handle the next phase.
author: iainmartin1

text: Isn't Robbins going anyway when (if) the WA is passed? Future relationship was always going to be handled by someone else.
author: iainmartin1

text: Get rid of May? Be serious John. The ERG propped May up for more than a year, and then botched her removal.
author: iainmartin1

text: They (millions of people) view it differently to you. Try, just once, to imagine that. They don't see it in narrow terms of self-interest. They see self-govt as elementary and worthwhile in itself.
author: iainmartin1

text: This by @dominicgates is terrific reporting, and shocking - what on earth were Boeing and US regulators thinking?
author: iainmartin1

text: Well put
author: iainmartin1

text: Indeed. It is complex. A lot of crosscurrents. Just pointing out that there is not a simple path to final two for a die hard.
author: iainmartin1

text: Indeed. Famed for their unity...
author: iainmartin1

text: The opposite - an anti-dealer will struggle to get to the final two.
author: iainmartin1

text: First they need to get past the parliamentary party - 314 MPs, 75 voted against the deal. Quite a few in the 314 will organise to block one of the 75.
author: iainmartin1

text: Love England. At half time my England fan friends were apologising. At the end we all agreed we had witnessed an extraordinary spectacle. I shouldn't have stood up and screamed "yes" in the middle of the England debenture seats when Scotland scored.
author: iainmartin1

text: But seriously, that twit aside it was a pretty good atmosphere?
author: iainmartin1

text: I can only apologise...
author: iainmartin1

text: It's from an anonymous People's Vote campaigner?
author: iainmartin1

text: There are 314 Tory MPs, and 75 voted against the deal last week. I suspect the majority will organise to block a die hard getting into the final two. Moderate Tory MPs I encountered last week seemed pretty fired up.
author: iainmartin1

text: Could be wrong, but doubt that will be the outcome because of the parliamentary party's role.
author: iainmartin1

text: Their tactics are very odd. Had quite a bit of leverage (in alliance with Labour and Remain-Tories) but they squandered it doing the "we're so angry" routine.
author: iainmartin1

text: Have you heard of the US primary system?
author: iainmartin1

text: Yes, I see that. But, still. Astonishing match. Miles behind. Facing another epic defeat. Draw!
author: iainmartin1

text: Sure, but next best thing and we were down and out at half time!
author: iainmartin1

text: Was glorious piece - but we got a draw and the most extraordinary comeback!
author: iainmartin1

text: Good grief, it's usually me that's the depressive and you are the realist.  Glory in the most hilarious afternoon of rugby for decades.
author: iainmartin1

text: Cheer up! We drew at Twickenham from 24 points behind! Was wonderful.
author: iainmartin1

text: Don't! Was hilarious. Rugby at its finest.
author: iainmartin1

text: Sure, but it was glorious, wasn't it?
author: iainmartin1

text: Wow. As a Scotland fan here at Twickenham don't really care we failed to win. It was the most glorious, absurd, wonderful match I've ever seen. Rugby at its best. #ENGvSCO #SixNations
author: iainmartin1

text: You're a nice guy!
author: iainmartin1

text: Are you here? It's like approaching the Coliseum.
author: iainmartin1

text: We last won here in 1983. But yes last year at Murrayfield was magnificent.
author: iainmartin1

text: Approaching Twickenham with usual Scotland fan's feelings of dread. Great line by  @AlasdairReid3 in @thetimes noting that Scotland squad has access to a sports psychologist but an expert in PTSD would be more appropriate after these fixtures.
author: iainmartin1

text: Yep
author: iainmartin1

text: Quite - she handles it with dignity.
author: iainmartin1

text: Pardon? I think the woke left is a menace, that the centre-left mainstream needs rebuilt and they are a barrier to that.
author: iainmartin1

text: The woke left is increasingly round the twist, approaching Maoist cultural revolution levels of fanaticism. It'll end up getting Trump reelected.
author: iainmartin1

text: Reminder, conservatives young and old don't march (usually busy and dislike mobs) and eurosceptics are amusingly terrible at holding rallies. The rally against the Lisbon Treaty was a like a thinly-attended episode of the Antiques Roadshow.
author: iainmartin1

text: Politicians oversell, shock. Never bought in to the wilder claims. Always thought it would be messy involving compromises, but at least outside the EU.
author: iainmartin1

text: I can't help you because you have FBPE in your Twitter bio. Very strict rules on this. Cannot respond to FBPE people. Sorry!
author: iainmartin1

text: What are you talking about? Have you so little imagination? Personally, spent the morning listening to a German conductor and German orchestra play the works of German composers. Love European culture. Don't like the EU. Can't you separate the two in your head?
author: iainmartin1

text: There's a lot left of the "dream". We're leaving the dreadful EU. Took us 14 years to get in. Will take us a few years to get out.
author: iainmartin1

text: What's the problem?
author: iainmartin1

text: DD didn't agree the sequencing. He objected,  opposed it, and was overruled by May on advice of officials.
author: iainmartin1

text: Why?
author: iainmartin1

text: You have that little faith in Britain? Why are you even bothering trying to leave?
author: iainmartin1

text: And completely overlooks that there are - if extension bid fails - the votes in parliament for a v long extension or more likely to revoke.
author: iainmartin1

text: What's weirdest about this argument is the failure of imagination. Brexiteers trapped by  Mayism, failing to conceive of changing circumstances by 2025 or a future PM having the gumption and guile of a Thatcher or Churchill.
author: iainmartin1

text: Have you taken this up with DD?
author: iainmartin1

text: March 29th?...
author: iainmartin1

text: if extension fails, and it's no deal, they will do it.
author: iainmartin1

text: Tory MPs! Switch on your brains! Vote for the deal. (Reposting this from a few days ago. Seems more relevant now. Anti-no deal MPs will revisit their attempt to take over. Election and/or revoke now likely. 75% Brexit better than 0% Brexit)
author: iainmartin1

text: anyone under 21 - began being free for registered students, had requests from people in work and paying taxes aged under 21.
author: iainmartin1

text: How Britain lost its sense of fairness and why we need to get it back. (Ben Fenton essay for Reaction @reactionlife)
author: iainmartin1

text: Parliament is doing its job and it is a magnificent sight. (Mark Fox for Reaction @reactionlife)
author: iainmartin1
